intro: Biscutella alireza-dadjua, commonly known as the Persian bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many economically important crops and weeds. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30 to 60 centimeters, featuring basal leaves and racemose inflorescences. Its flowers are usually pink or purple, with four petals arranged in a cross shape, characteristic of the Brassicaceae family. The plant is adapted to cold and arid environments, making it a hardy species found in rocky and alpine habitats.
